page.title: 03Geology of the area.
page.content:
The block lies just to the north of the southernmost limit of glaciation in the British Isles. Surface deposits over much of the area consist of boulder clay and it is only in the north-east of the area that there are more sandy deposits, though still of glacial origin.
These glacial deposits overlie London clay. London clay may actually be seen occasionally in the bed of the River Wid and its tributaries.
The geology of the area is responsible for the landscape and the character of farming in the block. Crop farming is the typical use of boulder clay lands. The sandy deposits in the north-east of the block help explain the greater incidence of woodland and non-arable land.
